tier_0_classification.classification_reasoning: This is a numerical calculation problem involving damped natural frequency for viscous damping and friction. It requires understanding of two different damping mechanisms and calculating the ratio, making it a multi-step problem.

answer_validation.correct_answer: 0.98 (ratio of Case 1 to Case 2 damped natural frequencies)
answer_validation.reasoning:
Natural frequency of the undamped system is given as 5 Hz, so the undamped angular frequency is $\omega_n = 2\pi f_n = 10\pi\,	ext{rad/s}$.

Case 1 (viscous damping, $\zeta = 0.2$):
Damped natural frequency is $\omega_{d1} = \omega_n\sqrt{1-\zeta^2} = 10\pi\sqrt{1-0.2^2} = 10\pi\sqrt{0.96}$. Numerically, $\sqrt{0.96} \approx 0.9799$, so $\omega_{d1} \approx 30.80\,	ext{rad/s}$.

Case 2 (Coulomb friction, $\mu = 0.01$):
For small Coulomb friction, the equivalent viscous damping ratio is approximately $\zeta_{eq} = \dfrac{2}{\pi}\dfrac{F_c}{kX_0}$, where $F_c = \mu N$ is the friction force and $X_0$ is the vibration amplitude. However, the question does not specify amplitude or normal force, so the intended GATE simplification is that the friction is very small ($\mu=0.01$) and its effect on the natural frequency is negligible. Thus, the damped natural frequency in Case 2 is taken approximately equal to the undamped natural frequency: $\omega_{d2} \approx \omega_n = 10\pi\,	ext{rad/s}$.

Therefore, the ratio of damped natural frequencies (Case 1 / Case 2) is
$$R =  rac{\omega_{d1}}{\omega_{d2}} = \sqrt{1-\zeta^2} = \sqrt{0.96} \approx 0.98.$$
This lies within the official answer range 0.970 to 0.990, so the key is consistent with the standard viscous-damping formula and the assumption that small dry friction does not significantly shift the natural frequency.

step_by_step: Identify the given data: undamped natural frequency $f_n = 5\,\text{Hz}$, so $\omega_n = 2\pi f_n = 10\pi\,\text{rad/s}$. Case 1 has viscous damping ratio $\zeta = 0.2$. Case 2 has small Coulomb friction with $\mu = 0.01$.
Recall the formula for damped natural frequency of a viscously damped SDOF system: $\omega_d = \omega_n\sqrt{1-\zeta^2}$.
Compute Case 1 damped natural frequency: $\omega_{d1} = 10\pi\sqrt{1-0.2^2} = 10\pi\sqrt{0.96}$. Numerically, $\sqrt{0.96} \approx 0.9799$, so $\omega_{d1} \approx 30.80\,\text{rad/s}$.

For Case 2 with dry friction, note that for small friction (here $\mu=0.01$) the primary effect is on amplitude decay, while the oscillation frequency remains very close to the undamped natural frequency. Thus, take $\omega_{d2} \approx \omega_n = 10\pi\,\text{rad/s}$.
Form the required ratio of damped natural frequencies (Case 1 / Case 2): $R = \omega_{d1}/\omega_{d2} = \sqrt{1-\zeta^2} = \sqrt{0.96} \approx 0.98$.
Round to three decimal places: $R \approx 0.980$, which lies within the official accepted range 0.970 to 0.990.

topic.name: Mechanical Vibrations (Single Degree of Freedom Systems)
topic.syllabus_ref: Section 3: Structures -> Structural Dynamics and Aeroelasticity -> Free and forced vibration of single degree of freedom systems

concepts.name: Damped natural frequency of viscously damped SDOF system
Damping ratio and its effect on frequency
Comparison of viscous and Coulomb (dry) damping
Undamped natural frequency of SDOF system

essential: Concept of natural frequency for a single degree of freedom spring-mass system
Definition and role of damping ratio in viscous damping
Formula for damped natural frequency in an underdamped viscous system
Basic understanding of Coulomb (dry) friction damping
Unit conversion between Hz and rad/s
helpful: Physical interpretation of how damping affects amplitude versus frequency
Awareness that small damping usually causes only a small shift in natural frequency

Main Concept: requires: Undamped natural frequency of SDOF system
requires: Damping ratio and viscous damping model
requires: Formula for damped natural frequency $\omega_d = \omega_n\sqrt{1-\zeta^2}$
enables: Comparison of different damping mechanisms (viscous vs Coulomb)
enables: Design of vibration isolation and control systems in aerospace structures

difficulty_factors: Requires remembering the exact form of the damped natural frequency formula
Needs the insight that small Coulomb friction does not significantly change the natural frequency
Students may overthink Case 2 and search for a complex formula instead of using the approximation

textbook_references.author: S. S. Rao
textbook_references.text_snippet: The equation of motion for a single-degree-of-freedom damped system in free vibration is $m\ddot{x}+c\dot{x}+kx=0$. For an underdamped system, the solution is $x(t)=e^{-\zeta\omega t}(A\cos\omega_D t + B\sin\omega_D t)$ where $\omega_D = \omega\sqrt{1-\zeta^2}$.

textbook_references.author: S. S. Rao
textbook_references.text_snippet: The relationship between the undamped natural frequency $\omega_n$ and the damped natural frequency $\omega_d$ is given by $\omega_d = \omega_n\sqrt{1-\zeta^2}$ for an underdamped system.

video_references.topic_covered: General solution for damped free vibration and definition of damped natural frequency

video_references.professor: Prof. S.K. Dwivedy and Prof. Rajiv Tiwari
video_references.topic_covered: Example of calculating undamped and damped natural frequencies for an underdamped SDOF system

step_by_step_solution.solution_path: Identify given data \u2192 Recall viscous damping frequency formula \u2192 Compute Case 1 frequency \u2192 Approximate Case 2 frequency as undamped \u2192 Form ratio \u2192 Numerically evaluate and round
key_insights: The damped natural frequency for viscous damping depends only on the damping ratio via $\sqrt{1-\zeta^2}$.
For small Coulomb friction, the frequency shift is negligible; the system oscillates nearly at the undamped natural frequency.
Because $\omega_n$ cancels in the ratio, the numerical value depends only on $\zeta$ for the chosen modeling assumptions.

formulas_principles.name: Relation between cyclic and angular natural frequency
formulas_principles.conditions: Applies for any linear SDOF system when converting Hz to rad/s
formulas_principles.relevance: Used to convert the given 5 Hz natural frequency into angular frequency for further calculations

formulas_principles.name: Damped natural frequency for viscously damped SDOF system
formulas_principles.conditions: Valid for underdamped viscous systems where $0<\zeta<1$
formulas_principles.relevance: Core formula to compute the damped natural frequency in Case 1

formulas_principles.name: Ratio of damped natural frequencies
formulas_principles.conditions: General definition of the required ratio between two cases
formulas_principles.relevance: Defines the quantity the question asks to compute

industry_examples: Design of landing gear shock struts where viscous damping is used to control oscillations without significantly altering the gear's natural frequency.
Vibration isolation mounts in avionics racks, where damping is tuned to reduce resonance peaks while maintaining acceptable natural frequencies.
specific_systems: Helicopter rotor blade lead-lag dampers, which use viscous or elastomeric damping to control oscillations.
Aircraft engine pylons with tuned mass dampers to reduce structural vibration transmitted to the wing.
real_world_applications.practical_relevance: Understanding how different damping mechanisms affect natural frequency helps engineers choose appropriate dampers that control vibration amplitudes without shifting resonance into dangerous operating ranges.

common_mistakes.why_students_make_it: They remember that damping reduces frequency and confuse the correct square-root relation with a linear approximation.
common_mistakes.how_to_avoid: Memorize the exact formula with the square root and the squared damping ratio; write it down whenever you start a damped vibration problem.
common_mistakes.consequence: Leads to a noticeably wrong ratio and can fall outside the accepted numerical range.

common_mistakes.mistake: Assuming that Coulomb friction in Case 2 gives the same frequency reduction formula as viscous damping and trying to compute a second $\omega_d$ using some guessed damping ratio.
common_mistakes.why_students_make_it: They expect a symmetric treatment of both cases and think every damping type must have a similar closed-form frequency formula.
common_mistakes.how_to_avoid: Recall that Coulomb damping primarily affects amplitude, not frequency, especially when friction is small. Unless a specific formula is given, treat the natural frequency as essentially unchanged.
common_mistakes.consequence: Unnecessary complexity and incorrect numerical values for the ratio.

common_mistakes.mistake: Forgetting to convert 5 Hz to rad/s and directly using 5 as $\omega_n$ in the formula.
common_mistakes.why_students_make_it: Under time pressure, they overlook the difference between Hz and rad/s.
common_mistakes.how_to_avoid: Always check units: if a formula uses $\omega$, convert from Hz using $\omega = 2\pi f$.
common_mistakes.consequence: Intermediate frequencies are wrong, though in this particular ratio problem $\omega_n$ cancels; in other problems this can cause large errors.

common_mistakes.mistake: Overthinking the effect of $\mu=0.01$ and trying to derive an exact equivalent viscous damping ratio without enough data (mass, stiffness, amplitude).
common_mistakes.why_students_make_it: They feel every given number must be used explicitly.
common_mistakes.how_to_avoid: Recognize that very small friction is often given to justify the approximation that frequency is nearly unchanged.
common_mistakes.consequence: Wastes time and may lead to abandoning the problem.

mnemonics_memory_aids.mnemonic: Damped = n times ROOT(1 minus zeta squared)
mnemonics_memory_aids.context: Use whenever you see an underdamped viscous SDOF system and need the damped natural frequency.

mnemonics_memory_aids.mnemonic: Zeta is squared, then rooted away
mnemonics_memory_aids.concept: Remembering that the damping ratio appears squared inside a square root in the frequency formula
mnemonics_memory_aids.context: While writing the formula to avoid missing the square on $\zeta$.

flashcards.front: What is the relation between undamped and damped natural frequency for an underdamped viscously damped SDOF system?
flashcards.back: $\omega_d = \omega_n\sqrt{1-\zeta^2}$, where $\zeta$ is the damping ratio and $0<\zeta<1$ for underdamped motion.

flashcards.front: Does small Coulomb (dry) friction significantly change the natural frequency of an SDOF system?
flashcards.back: For small Coulomb friction, the oscillation frequency remains very close to the undamped natural frequency; friction mainly affects amplitude decay, not frequency.

flashcards.front: Define damping ratio $\zeta$ for a viscously damped SDOF system.
flashcards.back: $\zeta = \dfrac{c}{c_c}$, where $c$ is the viscous damping coefficient and $c_c = 2m\omega_n$ is the critical damping coefficient.

flashcards.front: An SDOF system has $f_n = 5\,\text{Hz}$ and $\zeta = 0.2$. What is the ratio $\omega_d/\omega_n$?
Common error: writing $\omega_d = \omega_n(1-\zeta)$. Why is this wrong?
flashcards.back: The correct relation is $\omega_d = \omega_n\sqrt{1-\zeta^2}$. Frequency reduction depends on $\zeta^2$ and appears under a square root; using $(1-\zeta)$ overestimates the reduction.

real_world_context.application: Vibration control in aircraft fuselage and wing structures
real_world_context.industry_example: Designing damping treatments for cabin panels to reduce noise and vibration from engines and turbulence while keeping panel natural frequencies away from excitation frequencies.
real_world_context.why_it_matters: If damping changes the natural frequency too much, it can shift resonance into the operating range, increasing vibration and potentially causing fatigue or passenger discomfort.

real_world_context.industry_example: Choosing damping in oleo-pneumatic struts so that after touchdown the gear oscillates with reduced amplitude but without large changes in its natural frequency, avoiding coupling with fuselage modes.
real_world_context.why_it_matters: Incorrect damping can lead to uncomfortable or unsafe landing dynamics, including bouncing or shimmy.

exam_strategy.triage_tip: Recognize this as a quick vibration formula question: write $\omega_d = \omega_n\sqrt{1-\zeta^2}$, note that Case 2 frequency is essentially $\omega_n$, and compute the ratio as $\sqrt{0.96}$. It should take under 2 minutes.
exam_strategy.guessing_heuristic: If unsure, remember that moderate damping ($\zeta=0.2$) only slightly reduces frequency, so the ratio must be close to 1, around 0.97â€“0.99.
exam_strategy.time_management: Limit yourself to about 2 minutes. If you cannot recall the exact formula, move on and return later, as this is a low-mark but high-yield question.

search_keywords: damped natural frequency omega_d = omega_n sqrt(1 - zeta^2)
viscous damping ratio single degree of freedom system
Coulomb friction damping effect on natural frequency
GATE Aerospace vibrations SDOF damped free vibration
mechanical vibrations Rao damped free vibration
difference between viscous and dry friction damping

alternative_methods.name: Non-dimensional ratio approach
alternative_methods.description: Instead of computing $\omega_n$ explicitly, directly note that $\omega_{d1}/\omega_n = \sqrt{1-\zeta^2}$ and $\omega_{d2}/\omega_n \approx 1$, so the required ratio is simply $\sqrt{1-\zeta^2}$ without any numerical conversion from Hz to rad/s.
alternative_methods.pros_cons: Pros: Faster, avoids unit conversion and reduces arithmetic. Cons: Requires comfort with non-dimensional reasoning and the assumption that Coulomb friction does not change frequency.
alternative_methods.when_to_use: Useful in exams when time is short and the ratio structure is obvious.

connections_to_other_subjects.Flight Mechanics: Structural vibration characteristics of wings and control surfaces influence aeroelastic phenomena like flutter, which depend on natural frequencies and damping.
connections_to_other_subjects.Control Systems: Second-order system response in control theory uses the same parameters $\omega_n$ and $\zeta$ to describe transient behavior, overshoot, and settling time.
connections_to_other_subjects.Materials and Structures: Fatigue life predictions require knowledge of vibration amplitudes and frequencies under different damping conditions.

deeper_dive_topics: Equivalent viscous damping representation of Coulomb friction and its effect on system response
Nonlinear vibration analysis of systems with dry friction damping
Aeroelastic flutter analysis where structural damping and aerodynamic damping interact
Experimental determination of damping ratio using logarithmic decrement

syllabus_mapping.gate_subsection: Structural Dynamics and Aeroelasticity - Free and forced vibration of single degree of freedom systems
syllabus_mapping.feedback_for_syllabus_design: The question nicely tests core vibration formulas and conceptual understanding of different damping models without heavy computation, aligning well with the SDOF vibration part of the syllabus.

rag_quality.notes: RAG provided detailed explanations of damped free vibration, the formula $\omega_d = \omega_n\sqrt{1-\zeta^2}$, and example calculations of damped natural frequency and damping ratio. It did not directly address Coulomb friction damping, so the treatment of Case 2 relied on internal knowledge and standard approximations. Overall, RAG was helpful for the viscous damping part and general SDOF vibration context.

future_questions_potential: Given mass and stiffness, compute the critical damping coefficient and the damped natural frequency for a specified damping ratio.
Compare the decay of amplitude for viscous and Coulomb damping for the same SDOF system and initial conditions.
Design a damping ratio to limit the shift in natural frequency to less than 2% while achieving a specified logarithmic decrement.
For a given SDOF system with both viscous and Coulomb damping, qualitatively sketch and compare the time response.

response_json.subject: Aerospace Engineering
response_json.question_text: A single degree of freedom spring-mass system of natural frequency 5 Hz is modified in the following manners: Case 1: Viscous damping with damping ratio zeta = 0.2 is introduced in parallel to the spring. Case 2: The original undamped spring-mass system is moved to a surface with coefficient of friction, mu = 0.01. The ratio of the damped natural frequency for the cases 1 and 2 is given by __________ (in three decimal places).
